Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Novel Wireless Power Transmission Architecture for Devices Implanted in Human Bodies

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to verify a distributed power transmission architecture to deliver radio frequency power to devices implanted in human bodies. The proposed architecture aims to construct efficient and reliable wireless channels in complex in-body environments for power transfer. If proved feasible, it would fundamentally resolve a few problems associated with the state-of-the-art wireless charging technologies, including low efficiency, potential hazard to human health, and large and heavy apparatuses.

The intellectual merit is the proposed distributed power transmission architecture, which is potentially transformative to enable next-generation systems for wireless power delivery. Specifically, it has two major innovations. First, radio frequency power is transmitted via multiple antenna elements physically attached to a large area of skin and electrically matched to the skin. Second, the multiple antenna elements jointly behave as a retro-reflective beamformer: guided by the pilot signal sent from an implanted device, their radiations spatially converge to the target device with power intensities at all other locations below safety levels regulated for human.

The broader impacts include (i) promoting the contemporary Body Area Networks to the next level of integration; (ii) supporting both graduate and undergraduate students and provide them with excellent research opportunities; (iii) making constructive impacts to the science and engineering curricula at the three participating institutes; (iv) offering local high school students and teachers to participate in the proposed research activities; and (v) impacting both research and educational aspects of North Texas' high-tech industries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative research project involves three awards.  The major research objective at West Virginia University Research Corporation (that is, associated with Award 1303142) is to verify the fundamental concept of this project, wireless power transmission based on retro-reflective beamforming.

Retro-reflective beamforming is the key technique of this project.  The primary merit of retro-reflective beamforming constitutes employing radar tracking to guide wireless power transmission.  Specifically, wireless power transmission is initiated by pilot signals broadcasted from small electronic devices; and in response to the pilot signals, the wireless power transmitter delivers directional power beams to the devices.  During the project period, wireless power transmission based on retro-reflective beamforming has been verified comprehensively through a range of theoretical and experimental studies.  Our system experiments started with linear antenna arrays for the wireless power transmitter, and next, wireless power transmitters comprised of spatially-distributed antenna elements were studied.  Our numerical and experimental results successfully demonstrate that, retro-reflective beamforming scheme is capable of tracking a device’s location and focusing microwave power onto the device’s location.  Moreover, a theoretical framework is constructed for retro-reflective beamforming technique in the context of wireless power transmission.  Compared with conventional phased arrays, the antenna array employed in retro-reflective beamforming scheme behaves like a near-field focusing antenna; our research further indicates that, the far-zone gain associated with retro-reflective beamforming could be reduced by adjusting the array’s geometrical configuration without affecting focusing in the near-zone.

This project not only enables us to investigate retro-reflective beamforming as a wireless power transmission technique, but also facilitates us to gain better understanding about the underlying physics, time-reversal.  On the basis of this project, one of our proposals on time-reversal was awarded by the NSF in 2015 (with Award Number ECCS-1503600).  Through the NSF project awarded in 2015, we will continue investigating retro-reflective beamforming technique and apply it to a wider range of applications such as wireless communication and radar.  Research findings of this project were published in 1 book chapter, 6 journal papers, and 7 conference papers.  Eleven students were hired as research assistants in this project.  All of them performed certain research tasks together with the PI.  They were trained by the PI’s technical advice and gained practical research experience in the areas of electrical circuits and computer programming, which helps them become qualified engineers.  Throughout the project period, this project’s progress and outcomes were disseminated via many educational activities to high school teachers and students.  As a cutting-edge technology, wireless power transmission is well received by the high school teachers and students.  Feedback from high schools indicates that most high school teachers and students found this topic (that is, wireless power transmission) inspired their interest in science and technology.  In 2015, we were granted a US patent on retro-reflective beamforming technique.  We are actively seeking opportunities to commercialize the research outcomes of this project.
